Award.AwardTitle: Ergodic theory of infinite interval exchange transformations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves the extension of ergodic theoretic results about interval exchange transformations (IETs) to cases of interval exchanges involving infinitely many intervals. The primary question of interest is to classify the locally finite ergodic invariant measures of an infinite IET. Interest in the infinite case is motivated by connections between infinite IETs and more classical topics. Progress on these classes of examples will make significant contributions to the field of infinite ergodic theory, and to the subject of dynamical systems. Recently, the work of the principal investigator and others in the field have shown the existence of parallels between the theory of infinite IETs, and the much more well developed theory of horocyclic flows on non-compact hyperbolic surfaces. Motivated and directed by these connections, known results about infinite IETs will be extended and new results will be produced.

Dynamical systems is the study of any system which updates according to a fixed rule. For example, a finite number of particles behaving according to the rules of Newtonian mechanics is a dynamical system. This project concerns systems which are said to have low complexity, meaning that similar states for the system take a very long time to become dissimilar. These systems are of interest because they arise naturally from geometric, algebraic and physical questions. Despite the relevance of these systems, questions involving low complexity systems often can not be directly addressed by approaches prevalent in the theory of dynamical systems, because, for instance, these systems are not hyperbolic. This is particularly true for questions about the long term statistical behavior of low complexity systems. This project will extend the collection of tools which do apply to low complexity systems, and further extend the classes of systems to which these tools apply. Progress on these questions is of importance to the development and applicability of the theory of dynamical systems, which is one of the primary mathematical approaches available to understand the physical world. The PI will be working with undergraduates on related research during the summer.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A dynamical system is a state space together with an update rule which does not vary with time. Low complexity systems are dynamical systems for which nearby trajectories diverge very slowly. There are no general techniques to understand the long term behavior of a low complexity system, but the systems are important because of connections between this type of dynamical system and computing, physics, and other areas of mathematics such as geometry. Despite the lack of general methods, there is a general philosophical approach to understanding these dynamical systems. Typically, we use renormalization, which is an operation that repeatedly simplifies a dynamical system. If it can shown that significant simplifications can be made infinitely many times, then often these dynamical systems can be well understood. Work done on this award developed new renormalization techniques and broadened the applicability of renormalization methods to new classes of systems.


Some of the simplest systems of low complexity are interval exchange transformations, where an interval is cut up into finitely many pieces which are rearranged by translation to yield a bijection (invertible map). These systems have been actively studied for over 35 years, and progress is still being made on better understanding them. Work funded by this grant furthers progress in this subject, but also makes progress on understanding infinite interval exchange transformations (where the finiteness restriction mentioned above is removed). In a sense, all invertible dynamical systems can be interpreted as infinite interval exchange transformations, so work in this area is of broad interest.


Other classes of low complexity dynamical systems of interest were also studied under this grant. In the paper "Renormalization of Polygon Exchange Maps arising from Corner Percolation," a renormalization technique is developed which applies to a class of quasi-periodic tilings. (See attached image for one example tiling.) The renormalization process can be described on the level of the tilings, but also applies to a family of piecewise isometric transformations defined on a subset of the plane. These systems generalize interval exchange transformations in the sense that the maps are defined on polygons rather than intervals. New phenomena are proven to exist for systems of this type using these renormalization methods.


Students were mentored in subjects related to the research field described above. These students intend on pursuing careers in mathematics and mathematical education.
